user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_MutSemGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_MutSemGetInfo(osal_id_t sem_id, OS_mut_sem_prop_t *mut_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    int32               return_code;
    OS_object_token_t   token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(mut_prop);

    memset(mut_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_mut_sem_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_mutex_table, token);

        strncpy(mut_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(mut_prop->name) - 1);
        mut_prop->creator = record->creator;

        return_code = OS_MutSemGetInfo_Impl(&token, mut_prop);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_MutSemGetInfo:
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t creator;
} OS_mut_sem_prop_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_mutex_table
...
int32 OS_MutSemGetInfo_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_mut_sem_prop_t *mut_prop)
{
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No use of the Standard Library function memcmp is present in the provided code fragments. The function OS_MutSemGetInfo only calls memset (to zero the output struct) and strncpy (to copy the name) — neither of these compare null-terminated strings. The other referenced symbols/macros (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, OS_CHECK_POINTER, OS_MutSemGetInfo_Impl, OS_ObjectIdGetById, OS_ObjectIdRelease, OS_global_mutex_table) as provided do not perform string comparisons with memcmp either. Therefore there are no code fragments here that should be investigated for violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 (memcmp used to compare null-terminated strings). If analysis should extend beyond the supplied snippets, memcmp usage should be searched for in the rest of the codebase; but within the supplied code nothing matches the rule violation.
